image.altText: A close up of a Qantas plane's tail at an airport.

items.synopsis: The competition watchdog has launched legal action against Qantas for allegedly selling tickets for flights it had already cancelled, while the ASX has opened flat. Follow live.

title.children: ACCC takes Qantas to court for allegedly selling tickets for cancelled flights, ASX flat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has responded to the allegations made by the ACCC this morning regarding selling tickets to cancelled flights. Here's the airline's statement in full: "Qantas takes these allegations by the ACCC seriously," it said. "We have a longstanding approach to managing cancellations for flights, with a focus on providing customers with rebooking options or refunds. It's a process that is consistent with common practice at many other airlines. "It's important to note that the period examined by the ACCC between May and July 2022 was a time of unprecedented upheaval for the entire airline industry. "All airlines were experiencing well-publicised issues from a very challenging restart, with ongoing border uncertainty, industry wide staff shortages and fleet availability causing a lot of disruption. "We will examine the details of the ACCC's allegations and respond to them in full in court."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas responds to ACCC over cancelled flight sales allegations

children.content: Qantas has responded to the allegations made by the ACCC this morning regarding selling tickets to cancelled flights.
Here's the airline's statement in full:
"Qantas takes these allegations by the ACCC seriously," it said.
"We have a
longstanding approach to managing cancellations for flights
, with a focus on
providing customers with rebooking options or refunds
. It's a process that is consistent with
common practice at many other airlines
"It's important to note that the period examined by the ACCC between May and July 2022 was a time of unprecedented upheaval for the entire airline industry.

"All airlines were experiencing well-publicised issues from a very challenging restart, with ongoing border uncertainty, industry wide staff shortages and fleet availability causing a lot of disruption.
"We will examine the details of the ACCC's allegations and respond to them in full in court."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia Post has suffered a $200 million loss before tax for the 2023 financial year (down from a $55 million profit the previous year). It's just the second loss the organisation has posted since it became a self-funded government business enterprise in 1989. Growth in the parcels business was fairly flat, bringing in $7.3 billion in revenue. However, as expected, the letters business continues to decline, resulting in a loss of $384 million. The average Australian household receives only 2.2 addressed letters each week and that's expected to further halve in the next five years. Group chief executive offer Paul Graham said despite the organisation's efforts, it's not possible to stop the structural shift in the way Australians are using postal services. "If we do everything in our power to run this business well and we get a favourable regulatory response towards modernisation, I'm confident that Australia Post will return to profit," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia Post has delivered big losses

children.content: Australia Post has suffered a $200 million loss before tax for the 2023 financial year (down from a $55 million profit the previous year).
It's just the second loss the organisation has posted since it became a self-funded government business enterprise in 1989.
Growth in the parcels business was fairly flat, bringing in $7.3 billion in revenue.
However, as expected, the letters business continues to decline, resulting in a loss of $384 million.
The average Australian household receives only 2.2 addressed letters each week and that's expected to further halve in the next five years.
Group chief executive offer Paul Graham said despite the organisation's efforts, it's not possible to stop the structural shift in the way Australians are using postal services.
"If we do everything in our power to run this business well and we get a favourable regulatory response towards modernisation, I'm confident that Australia Post will return to profit," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has released a brief statement on the ACCC's legal action against Qantas over allegedly advertising and selling tickets for flights that had already been cancelled, in breach of Australian consumer law. "These are deeply concerning allegations ," he said. "We won't be commenting further on this particular case while the matter is before the courts. "This is the consumer watchdog doing its job and a reminder that businesses need to do the right thing by people — breaches of consumer law carry heavy penalties. "The Competition Review and the Aviation White Paper will consider issues related to competition in the aviation sector."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer says allegations against Qantas by the ACCC are 'deeply concerning'

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers
has released a brief statement on the ACCC's legal action against Qantas over allegedly
advertising and selling tickets for flights that had already been cancelled
, in breach of Australian consumer law.
"These are
deeply concerning allegations

"We won't be commenting further on this particular case while the matter is before the courts.
"This is the
consumer watchdog doing its job
and a reminder that
businesses need to do the right thing by people
— breaches of consumer law carry heavy penalties.
"The Competition Review and the Aviation White Paper will consider issues related to competition in the aviation sector."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: University of North Carolina students are calling for stricter state gun laws after associate professor Zijie Yan was shot dead earlier this week. At the rally, students described hours of terror and confusion during a lockdown and police manhunt that resulted in the arrest of a man who has been charged with first-degree murder and having a gun on educational property. March For Our Lives co-founder David Hogg urged students to take their pain and anger to the ballot box. "The reality is, if we don't mobilise after these things happen, they're going to continue happening," he said. "This is a critical state because this is where change is possible, a lot more than in Washington. "If students at UNC and elsewhere turned out and voted, they could change the state legislature."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: University students rally for gun safety after fatal shooting

children.content: (AP Photo: Hannah Schoenbaum)
University of North Carolina students are calling for stricter state gun laws after associate professor Zijie Yan was shot dead earlier this week.

At the rally, students described hours of terror and confusion during a lockdown and police manhunt that resulted in the arrest of a man who has been charged with first-degree murder and having a gun on educational property.
(AP Photo: Hannah Schoenbaum)
March For Our Lives co-founder David Hogg urged students to take their pain and anger to the ballot box.
"The reality is, if we don't mobilise after these things happen, they're going to continue happening," he said.
"This is a critical state because this is where change is possible, a lot more than in Washington.
"If students at UNC and elsewhere turned out and voted, they could change the state legislature."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ukraine's military has confirmed six Ukrainian servicemen have been killed aboard two helicopters while "carrying out missions." Local media reports the incident occurred near Kramatorsk, where much of the fighting has been taking place since Russia's invasion 18 months ago. Reports suggest the two helicopters were "completely destroyed" and bodies have been found at the crash site. Officials say a service for the men will take place on Thursday local time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ukraine's military confirms multiple deaths after helicopter crash

children.content: Ukraine's military has confirmed six Ukrainian servicemen have been killed aboard two helicopters while "carrying out missions."
Local media reports the incident occurred near Kramatorsk,
where much of the fighting has been taking place since Russia's invasion 18 months ago.
Reports suggest the two helicopters were "completely destroyed" and bodies have been found at the crash site.
Officials say a service for the men will take place on Thursday local time.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The prime minister says he's convinced voters in the crucial state of Tasmania will vote Yes in the Voice referendum. Anthony Albanese will visit Hobart and Launceston on the first full day of campaigning since confirming the poll will be held on October 14. After spending yesterday in Hobart, No campaign leaders will head to Adelaide today — in a further sign Tasmania and South Australia are shaping up to be key states in the vote. Mr Albanese has told Triple-M Radio he's confident the referendum will succeed. "I am convinced Tasmanians will vote Yes," he said. "I will be with the Premier Jeremy Rockliff this morning, and then with Bridget Archer in Launceston this afternoon, both of them being strong Yes supporters."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM: 'Tasmanians will vote Yes'

children.content: The prime minister says he's convinced voters in the crucial state of Tasmania will vote Yes in the
Voice referendum
Anthony Albanese will visit Hobart and Launceston on the first full day of campaigning since confirming the poll will be held on October 14.
After spending yesterday in Hobart, No campaign leaders will head to Adelaide today — in a further sign Tasmania and South Australia are shaping up to be key states in the vote.
Mr Albanese has told Triple-M Radio he's confident the referendum will succeed.
"I am convinced Tasmanians will vote Yes," he said.
"I will be with the Premier Jeremy Rockliff this morning, and then with Bridget Archer in Launceston this afternoon, both of them being strong Yes supporters."
